intro: Vernonia leptophylla, commonly known as the narrow-leaf ironweed, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its tall, slender stems and clusters of small, blue to violet flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant has lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, giving it a slightly fuzzy appearance. Vernonia leptophylla is a member of the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is known for its ecological importance to pollinators. It thrives in full sun and well-drained soil, making it a hardy addition to native gardens.
